metadata.title: Evolution of nano-laminated structure formed by the thermally-assisted plastic deformation in dry sliding wear

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Tribology International
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/triboint
Evolution of nano-laminated structure formed by the thermally-assisted plastic deformation in dry sliding wear
Yun-Shuai Sua, Shu-Xin Lia,∗, Qing-Yuan Gaoa, Hai Jianga, Si-Yuan Lua, Feng Yua, Xue-Dao Shua,b
a School of Mechanical Engineering and Mechanics, Ningbo University, Ningbo, 315211, PR China b Key Laboratory of Part Rolling of Zhejiang Province, Ningbo University, Ningbo, 315211, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-laminated structure Dry sliding wear Gradient structure Dislocation cell blocks
A B S T R A C T
The evolution of nano-laminated structure generated in dry sliding wear of a high strength martensite steel was investigated by using Scanning Electronic Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). Gradient microstructure along the depth was observed with the top layer consisting of nano-laminated structure. During the sliding wear-induced plastic deformation, grains were refined and lamellar structures were formed as a result of generation of dislocation cell blocks bounded by geometrically necessary boundaries (GNBs) and incidental dislocation boundaries (IDBs). With increasing plastic shear strain and strain gradient, there is a continuous reduction in the spacing and length in dislocation cell blocks, leading to nano-laminated structures. The ultrafine nano-laminated structure with laminate spacing of 20 nm was observed at the sliding time of 120min. However, the grain refinement is not a merely mechanical deformation process. The formation of Fe3O4 and FeO gave direct evidence that the highest temperature due to frictional heat could reach up to 600 °C. The result suggested that the formation of nano-laminated structure was governed by thermally-assisted plastic deformation.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Sliding wear is of great importance for tribological parts such as gears, bearings and rail wheels. Sliding wear can induce large plastic deformation. As a result, nanocrystallines or nano-laminated structures were formed in frictional contact surfaces [1–3]. The grain refinement by sliding wear-induced plastic deformation is similar to severe plastic deformation (SPD) such as surface mechanical grinding treatment [4,5], high pressure torsion [6] and equal channel angular pressing [7] etc. SPD is generally employed to refine microstructures of polycrystalline metallic materials to improve strength and ductility. However, sliding wear was largely reported due to its influence on tribology properties caused by microstructural change, which can be either positive or negative effects [8–10]. The recent study by Yin et al. [11] presented that a self-lubricating layer was formed in martensite and pearlite materials when an amorphous oxide was generated combined with the oxidation of nano-lamellar structures during the sliding wear.
Gradient microstructure induced by sliding wear has been extensively studied in various materials regarding Cu and Cu alloys [12,13], Al alloys [14], Mg alloys [15], Ti alloys [16], austenitic stainless steels [15], perlite rail steels [17], high strength martensite steels of 20CrMnTi [18] and 20CrNi2Mo [19], etc. The formation of
nanocrystallines or nano-laminated structures is mainly attributed to large plastic shear deformation. Apart from the mechanism of mechanical deformation, temperature-related mechanisms are also involved in the sliding wear process, such as recrystallizaiton, dynamical recrystallizaiton (DRX) and even melting. The observation of a number of equiaxed grains indicated that the DRX occurred in polycrystalline copper [20] and aluminum alloys [21]. DRX can inhibit the continuous development of nanocrystalline tribolayer of copper at high sliding speed [8]. Through controlling the DRX process such as increasing the grain size, the sliding wear resistance of Cu-2.2 wt% Al alloy can be significantly improved due to the change in the wear mechanism [10]. However, the target materials in these studies were focused on low strength metallic alloys, whose DRX temperatures are not more than 300 °C. As for high strength materials with much higher DRX temperature over 700 °C, it was reported that the formation of nano-laminated structures was controlled by plastic deformation without involving DRX or thermal effect [18,19]. Besides, in addition to materials, frictional wear parameters also have a significant influence on the formation mechanism. For example, melting was observed in rollingsliding wear of aluminum bronze again steel under high speed friction and heavy load [22,23]. In the case of very high frictional speed and large frictional contact surface, local melting occurred in the martensite
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.triboint.2019.105846 Received 20 March 2019; Received in revised form 30 May 2019; Accepted 24 June 2019
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: lishuxin@nbu.edu.cn (S.-X. Li).
Tribology International 140 (2019) 105846
Available online 25 June 2019 0301-679X/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
steel of AISI 52100 [24], indicating that the temperature rise due to frictional heating could reach up to 1500 °C. Since the mechanism is dependent on both materials and sliding wear parameters, the following questions are raised:
(1) Is the conventional dry sliding wear influenced by frictional heating? (2) If so, what is the highest temperature rise due to frictional heating in high strength martensite steel? (3) What is the formation mechanism of nano-laminated structure?
The present study aims to answer the questions. The dry sliding wear test was conducted on a high strength martensite steel. The evolution of nano-laminated structures was investigated at various sliding times. Temperature rise induced by friction heating was estimated and verified by wear debris. The emphasis was placed on the formation mechanism of nano-laminated structures.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The material used for dry sliding test is a tempered martensitic steel. The chemical composition is as follows (wt.%): C, 0.95; Mn, 0.30; Cr, 1.48; Si, 0.25; S, ≤ 0.020; P, ≤ 0.027. Fe, balance. The material was heat treated at 930 °C and held at this temperature for 1 h, followed by quenching in oil to room temperature. Then tempered at 180 °C for 1 h followed by air cooling. The average hardness was 605 HV.
The dry sliding wear test was conducted on a ball-on-disc friction wear system. The diameter and thickness of the disc specimen are 30 and 5mm, respectively. The specimens were polished before testing with the surface roughness of 0.05～0.1 μm. The grinding ball has the same material with the disc, 6 mm in diameter and fixed to a fixture. The test was carried out in room temperature (25 °C) at the load of 150 N with the sliding time of 30, 60 and 120min. The relative velocity is 0.314m/s corresponding to 500 rpm. Coefficient of friction (COF) was measured during the test. Meanwhile, the surface temperature variation was monitored using an infrared thermal imaging camera. The mass difference in weight before and after the test was measured by an electronic balance.
After the test, the 3D worn groove was inspected using a confocal laser scanning microscopy [3,25]. The disc specimens were sectioned along the circumferential direction. They were grounded, polished and then etched with a 2% nitric acid alcohol solution. The cross section microstructure was inspected by a SU-5000 scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a FEI Talos F200X transmission electron microscope (TEM). TEM samples were prepared by focused ion beam (FIB) technique. Micro-hardness along the depth was measured using a microindentation hardness testing machine with the load of 50 g and holding time of 10 s.

sections.heading: 3.1. Coefficient of friction (COF) variation
sections.text:
The variation of the COF with the time is given in Fig. 1. The COF rises sharply during the first 10 min until it reached 0.5–0.55. This value was kept with small variation till the end of the test. The COF can be influenced by frictional parameters such as sliding speed, contact frequency, environment temperature and vacuum [26–28]. In some cases, the influence is not a simple positive or negative correlation. For example, with increasing normal load, the COF increased at a small sliding speed of 0.065m/s, but decreased at a high sliding speed of 0.13m/s [19]. When the sliding speed was raised ten times higher from 0.015m/s to 0.15, there was a slight change in the COF from 0.60 to 0.67. It was reported that the slight variation in the COF indicates that the materials went through the same wear mechanism [29]. The COF of 0.55 is used for the calculation of frictional heat in the discussion
section.

sections.heading: 3.2. Microhardness variation
sections.text: The micro-indentation test was carried out at an interval of 10 μm beneath the worn surface. The result is illustrated in Fig. 2. The hardness drops along the depth with the maximum at the surface. In the range of 50 μm deep, the drop is dramatic with the hardness from 725 to 630 HV at 120min. Then it tends to reach the matrix hardness of 605 HV. The similar microhardness variation has been commonly seen in sliding wear or surface mechanical grinding treatment [4,30–32]. The hardness increase is mainly attributed to the refined microstructure. Grains are refined due to the sliding wear-induced plastic deformation, with the top surface consisting of nano-laminated structures, as will be seen in the following TEM micrographs.

sections.heading: 3.3. SEM microstructures
sections.text:
The cross-sections of the worn surface were inspected by SEM. The typical micrograph was illustrated in Fig. 3 (a), which was taken from
the sample at the load of 150 N, relative velocity of 0.314m/s, and the sliding time of 60min. It can be seen that the sliding-induced plastic deformation is highly inhomogeneous along the depth. A gradient microstructure was formed. The top surface has the largest plastic deformation. In contrast to the matrix microstructure in Fig. 3 (b), three layers are present in the subsurface, as marked in Fig. 3 (a). The topmost layer I, the average depth of 6 μm, displays an ultrafine microstructure, which can hardly be identified by SEM. At the depth range of 6–12 μm, labeled II, it consists of substantially sheared and elongated microstructure with the elongation inclined 15°–20° to the sliding surface. Below is the bent martensite III, presenting curved and elongated grains. The gradient microstructure is consistent with the observations in the surface friction-induced plastic deformation [2,4,19]. It is noted that the plastic deformation is not only depth-dependent, but the local microstructure-dependent as well. At the same depth, the magnitude of plastic deformation is not homogeneous. On the right hand side of the Fig. 3 (a), the depth of the ultrafine microstructures layer is the smallest, but it has the biggest depth span of bent martensite layer. On the left hand side, the bent martensite takes up the smallest part. This phenomenon is commonly seen in the SEM inspection.

sections.heading: 3.4. TEM microstructures
sections.text:
The microstructure evolution can be revealed from the TEM micrographs at the depth span of 0–6 μm for various sliding times of 30, 60 and 120min in Fig. 4. For the sliding time of 30min, the microstructure appears to be elongated parallel to the sliding direction in Fig. 4 (a). The microstructure is characterized as very high density of dislocations and substructures. It was observed that the elongated grains are fragmented into smaller substructures and fine grains by entangled dislocations clustered inside of grains. Comparing with the microstructure at 30min, the lamellar structure is clearly presented at 60min in Fig. 4 (b). The microstructure is characterized as dislocations and cell blocks. The average spacing and the length of laminates are 38 nm and 120 nm respectively. A number of ultrafine grains with the size of 20–50 nm are randomly distributed, marked by arrows in Fig. 4 (b). The nano-laminated structure is even more apparent at 120min in Fig. 4 (c). The spacing between laminates shrank to 20 nm averagely, forming the ultrafine nano-laminated structure. In contrast, the length has a slow reduction, changing from 120 nm to 115 nm. Some ultrafine grains below 20 nm were observed in the cell blocks.
Fig. 5 presents the typical gradient microstructure along the depth for the sliding time of 120min. At the depth of 6–12 μm in Fig. 5 (a), the similar nano-laminated structure was observed apart from the increased laminate spacing to 35 nm, larger than 20 nm at the depth of 0–6 μm in Fig. 4 (c). The microstructure at the 12–18 μm deep in Fig. 5 (b) does not show lamellar structure. Rather, it consists of substantially refined nano grains, elongated grains and substructures dominated by
dislocations. Grains ranging 50–100 nm tend to be equiaxed grains, as circled by dotted lines in Fig. 5 (b). The microstructure below 18 μm deep is bent and deformed martensite, whose grains were partitioned into substructures at places indicated by arrows in Fig. 5 (c).

sections.heading: 4.1. Estimation of plastic shear strain and strain gradient
sections.text:
As can be seen from the above TEM microstructures, the gradient microstructure was formed in the worn surface with the top layer consisting of nano-laminated structures. The gradient microstructure is due to the existence of a large shear strain and strain gradient along the depth in the sliding wear [1,9]. The shear strain and the strain gradient can be quantitatively estimated by measuring either the shear angle θ or the displacement on cross-section micrographs.
As for measuring the shear angle θ, the equivalent strain is given by ε= tan (θ)/√3. The method, developed by Dautzenberg and Zaat [33], has been used to estimate the equivalent strain in worn and deformed surfaces [18,19,34,35]. However, the shear angle θ is hard to be measured precisely for heavily deformed area [33]. In view of this, an alternative way was given by the authors to calculate a severely sheared grain. The grain was assumed as spherical with the diameter of D and the thickness of c. The normal shear strain can be obtained by = − ≈ ≫( )ε D c1 ( )Dc DC 1 22 2 . H. Sato [32] employed this method to estimate the strain in wear-induced layer of functionally graded material. However, the estimation is very sensitive to the radius and thicknesses of grains.
The shear strain can also be estimated by means of measuring the displacement on the cross-section micrographs [4,19,36]. Moore and Douthwaite [37] obtained the shear strain on the worn surface consisting of the copper laminae separated by melt and solidified solder. It showed that the strain distribution can be described by an exponential relationship. The displacement y can be represented by Refs. [4,36]:
= −y x y exp kx( ) ( )s (1)
where x is the depth beneath the depth; ys is the displacement at the worn surface, shown in Fig. 3 (a). Here, we take the SEM micrograph at 120min as a typical example. The displacement variation with the depth can be fitted by log (y)=−0.303 x+6.46. The shear strain ε can be denoted as the partial derivative of the displacement function with respect to the depth x:
= − ∂ ∂ = −ε x y x x x( ) ( ) 193 exp( 0.303 ) (2)
Further, the strain gradient grad ε is given by the partial derivative of the shear strain with respect to x.
∂ ∂ = −ε x x exp x( ) 58 ( 0.303 ) (3)
The shear strain ε was estimated based on the above two methods. The result is given in Fig. 6 (a). It was found that the shear strains of both methods follow exponential relationship. The topmost layer has the largest shear strain. It increases dramatically with the sliding time and decreases sharply in the depth span of 0–10 μm. At 30 and 60min, the angle measurement gives larger shear strain than the displacement, but the estimations are very close at the large strain at 120min. For the sake of simplicity, we take the displacement method as the objective for analysis. The maximum strain at 120min was 193, 4 times larger than 60min and 12 times larger than 30min. The shear strain estimation was reported to range from 10 to over100 depending on plastic deformation [4,11,13,32].
The strain gradient grad ε was calculated and plotted in Fig. 6 (b). Almost the same increment was observed for the strain gradient variation. The maximum strain gradient increased from 4.24 μm−1 at 30 min to 58.9 μm−1 at 120min. The estimation is comparable to the result in the martensite steel of 20CrNi2Mo by sliding wear corresponding to the shear strain of 26.83 μm−1 at the depth of 6.4 μm [19].

sections.heading: 4.2. Estimation of temperature rise due to frictional heating
sections.text:
The temperature rise due to frictional heating is inevitable in the sliding surface [38]. The magnitude of temperature rise depends on materials and sliding wear conditions such as sliding speed and contact load [39]. It has been a challenge for temperature estimation due to the complexity of friction. Both theoretical and experimental work have been carried out [40,41]. It should be noted that a precise calculation of the temperature rise is beyond the scope of the present study. Our purpose is to estimate the lower and upper bounds of temperature in order to reveal its influence on the formation of nano-laminated structures.
The surface temperature was measured by using an infrared thermal imaging camera placed 10mm away from the contact point. The result is given in Fig. 7. The temperature climbs dramatically for the first 10min until it reached about 170 °C. Then it keeps at this level with small fluctuation of less than 20 °C at some points till the end of the test. The change is same in all tests for 30min, 60min and 120min. The measured temperature is consistent with the results in dry sliding of Al–Si–Mg alloys [42] and Ni–W [29]. The frictional heat is dissipated mainly through heat conduction to the surrounding, generation of wear debris, plastic deformation and increasing temperature of the material [43–45]. In view of this, the measurement of 170 °C can be regarded as the end temperature, namely the lower bound in the present condition.
Regarding the upper bound of the temperature, we consider a onedimensional transient heat flow model, which has been used in sliding wear of nanocrystalline Ni–W [29] and friction layer of Ni3Al matrix composites [46]. This model was specifically applied to pin-on-disk contact type, which is the case in our sliding contact geometry. It was assumed that the frictional heat dissipates by convention at the surface and conduction into the subsurface at the contact point. The local surface temperature can be expressed as [47]:
= ⎧ ⎨⎩ − ⎡ ⎣ ⎢
⎤ ⎦ ⎥ ⎡ ⎣⎢ ⎤ ⎦⎥ ⎫ ⎬⎭ T Q h erfc h t Kρc exp h t Kρc 1 ·A s s s 2
(4)
where hs: the convection heat transfer coefficient, t: the time, c: the specific heat; ρ: the density; K: the thermal conductivity; QA: the frictional heat per unit area, which can be calculated from QA= μPv/As, where μ: the COF; P: the normal load; As: the surface area in circumference. The specific values are given in Table 1.
The calculation of the circumferential surface area As is based on the 3D worn track morphology shown in Fig. 8. The topmost surface has the maximum temperature as this is where the friction heating originates. Substituting the quantities in Table 1 into Eq. (4), it gives the upper bound of 1322 °C for 120min.
The actual maximum temperature can be inferred from the composition of wear debris and microstructural features. The wear debris was collected and examined by SEM and XRD. The results are displayed in Fig. 9 (a) and (b). The XRD inspection showed that the wear debris is composed of α-Fe and Fe3O4. Also, a small amount of FeO was detected. For comparison, an additional sliding wear test was conducted at a lower sliding speed 0.13m/s, whose composition of the worn debris is mainly Fe2O3, shown in Fig. 9 (b). The difference in oxidation is due to the change in temperature [49,50]. It was reported that the oxide Fe2O3 is observed at the temperature below 450 °C. But Fe3O4 and FeO are the high temperature oxidation products and are generated at 450–600 °C for Fe3O4 and over 600 °C for FeO [27,51,52].
The presence of Fe3O4 and FeO gives direct evidence that the temperature rise can reach over 600 °C in the present sliding wear. If the temperature could rise up to above 750 °C (the DRX temperature for the
martensite steel, ∼0.5 Tm, where Tm is the melting point of 1500 °C [53]), the DRX will be trigged. However, the TEM inspection showed that the nano-laminated structure was characterized by high density of locations. Dislocation-free equiaxed grains with well-defined grain boundaries were not observed. This indicated that the DRX did not occur. Thus, it can be suggested that the temperature rise is below 750 °C. Although some grains present clear boundaries and tend to be equiaxed, as indicated by the arrows and circles in Fig. 10 (a) (taken at the depth of around 7 μm in the sample of 60min), this could possibly be the result of partial recrystallization.
The above analysis showed that the temperature rise can reach above 600 °C, but below 750 °C. For the sake of conservative estimation, we regard the maximum temperature as 600 °C. However, it should be noted that the material was not subjected to the high temperature of 600 °C continuously. Rather, it fluctuated between 170 and 600 °C due to the heat dissipation and the nature of cyclic sliding wear.

sections.heading: 4.3. Formation mechanism of nano-laminated structure
sections.text:
The TEM inspection showed that the nano-laminated structure was formed in dry sliding wear. Nano-laminated structures induced by plastic deformation have been widely seen in shear-dominated severe plastic deformation [4,5]. Under large shear plastic deformation, grains were sheared and elongated parallel to the shear direction. Then elongated grains were continuously refined during the sliding wear process. TEM morphologies demonstrated that the nano-laminated structure is characterized by dislocation cell blocks bounded by geometrically necessary boundaries (GNBs). Inside of the GNBs, dislocation cells were separated into smaller cells by incidental dislocation boundaries (IDBs) [54]. Both GNBs and IDBs are illustrated by longitudinal solid lines and transverse short lines, respectively in Fig. 10 (b). The cell blocks are labeled as A, B, C.
As discussed above, the large plastic strain and strain gradient were generated in the worn-affected layer. Large strain gradient facilitates the formation of nano-laminated structures [55,56]. With increasing plastic strain and strain gradient, the number of cell blocks and GNBs were greatly enhanced in order to accommodate the increasing density of dislocations [1,4]. The number of GNBs and IDBs is significantly increased as a result of laminate spacing reduction from 38 nm at 60min to 20 nm at 120min in Fig. 4. The continuous shrink in the spacing leads to the formation of nano-laminated structure. It was observed that the dislocation cell block can be separated into two parallel
GNBs, as displayed by the red dotted lines in Fig. 11, causing further reduction in the spacing of cell blocks. In contrast, the growth of the number of IDBs is much slower than that of GNBs. The laminates do not show distinctive change in the length from 60min to 120min in Fig. 4. Some grains were substantially refined and lots of grains below 20 nm were observed. The grain refinement can be seen from the TEM dark field image in Fig. 11, where the nano laminate was partitioned into nano-sized grains.
However, the grain refinement is not a merely mechanical deformation process. The analysis showed that the temperature varies from 170 to 600 °C. The material becomes easier to deform when it is subjected to large shear plastic deformation at 170–600 °C during the long duration of 60 and 120min. This facilitates the formation of nanolaminated structures. The underlying mechanism could be related to the material softening due to recovery of dislocations at this temperature range [57]. The sliding wear is actually fatigue loading process [58]. Assisted by the frictional heating, cyclic softening would occur. The phenomenon is referred as fatigue ratcheting. But this point is beyond the topic of the current study and will not be discussed in-depth. In fact, the cyclic softening was observed during the sliding wear in Copper [59]. It was attributed to partial recrystallisation and was evidenced by the cube-type texture. In the current study, the temperature rise is below the DRX temperature of 750 °C as the DRX is not supported by TEM microstructures. But partial recrystallization is evidenced by welldefined grains in Fig. 10. Therefore, it can be suggested that the formation of nano-laminated structure is controlled by the sliding wear-
induced plastic deformation and assisted by thermal effect.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The nano-laminated structure induced by dry sliding wear in the martensite steel was characterized using SEM and TEM. A picture of how the lamellar structure evolved with the sliding time was given. The main conclusion includes:
1) The shear strain and strain gradient increased with the increasing sliding time from 30 to 120min. The maximum shear strain was 193 for 120min, 4 times larger than the result for 60min and 12 times larger for 30min. Almost the same increment was observed for the strain gradient variation with the sliding time. The shear strain and strain gradient estimations are in agreement with the results of the existing reports of gradient structures. 2) The microstructure evolution from the sliding time of 30–120min was presented. The TEM result showed that the microstructure for 30min was characterized as very high density of dislocations and substructures, without showing lamellar structure. The nano-laminated structure was clearly presented with the spacing of laminate of 38 nm for 60min. The microstructure was characterized as dislocation cell blocks. With increasing shear strain and strain gradient for 120min, the ultrafine nano-laminated structure was formed. The spacing of laminate shrank to 20 nm. Ultrafine grains below 20 nm were observed interior of dislocations cell blocks. 3) The lower and upper bounds of temperature rise due to frictional heating were given. The temperature varied from 170 to 600 °C. The formation of Fe3O4 and FeO indicated that the temperature rise can rise up to 600 °C, but below the DRX temperature of 750 °C. The partial recrystallization was evidenced by some well-defined grains in TEM micrographs. 4) The formation of the nano-laminated structure is a process where dislocation cell blocks and elongated grains were fragmented by continuously generated GNBs and IDBs. It was suggested that this process is not merely a mechanical process. Rather, it was affected by thermal effect due to the temperature rise in frictional heating.

sections.text: This work was financially supported by Natural Science Foundation of China NSFC (No. 51675287) and K.C. Wong Magna Fund in Ningbo University.

metadata.abstractText: The evolution of nano-laminated structure generated in dry sliding wear of a high strength martensite steel was investigated by using Scanning Electronic Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). Gradient microstructure along the depth was observed with the top layer consisting of nano-laminated structure. During the sliding wear-induced plastic deformation, grains were refined and lamellar structures were formed as a result of generation of dislocation cell blocks bounded by geometrically necessary boundaries (GNBs) and incidental dislocation boundaries (IDBs). With increasing plastic shear strain and strain gradient, there is a continuous reduction in the spacing and length in dislocation cell blocks, leading to nano-laminated structures. The ultrafine nano-laminated structure with laminate spacing of 20 nm was observed at the sliding time of 120min. However, the grain refinement is not a merely mechanical deformation process. The formation of Fe3O4 and FeO gave direct evidence that the highest temperature due to frictional heat could reach up to 600 °C. The result suggested that the formation of nano-laminated structure was governed by thermally-assisted plastic
